answers.q: how does benzole peroxide reduce acne
answers.a: As a topical drug, benzoyl peroxide reduces acne by releasing oxygen that kills acne-causing bacteria and helps keep pores from clogging; as a food additive (E928) it’s used to bleach flour, not to treat acne.
In foods, benzoyl peroxide (E928) is a strong oxidizing flour-bleaching/maturing agent that whitens flour pigments and then breaks down mainly to benzoic acid and oxygen.

answers.q: how to prevent bleached eyebrows benzole peroxide
answers.a: Because it’s a bleaching oxidizer, keep products away from hair/eyebrows, apply carefully, use a barrier (e.g., petroleum jelly) along the hairline, and rinse hands and any residue off promptly.

In food processing, small regulated amounts are uniformly blended into flour to bleach and mature it; for topical acne products, follow the label and start with lower strengths due to irritation and bleaching risk.

answers.q: what store sells benzole peroxide shampoo
answers.a: Benzoyl peroxide is uncommon in human shampoos (it can bleach hair) and is mainly sold as acne washes at pharmacies or online; as E928 it’s an industrial flour-bleaching aid, not a consumer shampoo.

In foods, E928 (benzoyl peroxide) is a flour-treatment/bleaching agent that whitens flour and can slightly improve dough handling; it decomposes during processing so very little remains in the finished product.
No—it doesn’t bleach living skin, though it can lighten hair and fabrics; in food it’s used to bleach flour, not skin.
No; the tiny amounts used in flour don’t cause skin “purging”—that term relates to topical acne treatments, which is unrelated to food use.
It acts as a strong oxidizing agent, releasing oxygen that bleaches yellow carotenoid pigments in flour; in the process it breaks down mainly to benzoic acid/benzoate.
At approved levels for flour bleaching in some countries, it’s considered safe and leaves minimal residues as benzoic acid; it is not permitted for this use in the EU.
